facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 175 of 1951 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 175 of 1951. Appeal by Special Leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from High Court order dated 30th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: from the Order and Decree dated the 30th March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Ramaswami and Rai JJ.

facts.text: High Court Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951 arose from Additional Sub-Judge order dated 18th December 1950 in Title Suit No. 47 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951 arising out of the Order dated the 18th December, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sub-Judge Second at Gaya in Title Suit No. 47 of 1950.

facts.text: State of Bihar made application under section 34 of Indian Arbitration Act against Gaya Electric Supply Co. Ltd. for stay of suit filed on 28th September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of an application made by the State of Bihar against the Gaya Electric Supply Co. Ltd. under section 34 of the Indian- Arbitration Act for stay of proceedings in a suit filed by the companypany on 28th September, 1950.

facts.text: Licence for supply of electric energy in Gaya obtained by Khandelwal in 1928 under Indian Electricity Act 1910.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to this enquiry are these. A licence of or the supply of electric energy in the town of Gaya was obtained by one Khandelwal in the year 1928 under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

facts.text: Licence transferred to company in 1932 with Government sanction.

anchor.surface_text: With the required sanction of the Government the licence was transferred to the companypany in 1932.

facts.text: Licence revoked by notification dated 23rd June 1949 effective 9th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated 23rd June, 1949, the licence was revoked by the Government with effect from 9th July, 1949.

facts.text: Company filed suit No. 58 of 1949 against State for declaration that revocation was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the companypany filed a suit against the State for a declaration that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

facts.text: Deed of agreement arrived at between company and State on 28th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit negotiations started between the companypany and the State for a settlement of the dispute and ultimately on 28th October, 1949, a deed of agreement was arrived at between them.

facts.text: Agreement provided company would withdraw suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the agreement and the companyrespondence referred to therein was substantially as follows - That the companypany would withdraw the suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October, 1949.

facts.text: State to make advance payment of Rs. five lakhs within three days of suit withdrawal, company to hand over possession.

anchor.surface_text: That within three days of the withdrawal of ,the suit the State of Bihar would make an advance payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany, and, simultaneously the companypany would formally hand over the possession of the undertaking to an authorized officer of the Government.

facts.text: Parties to make valuations within three months of taking over undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: That both parties will make their respective valuations within three months of talking over the undertaking and any balance of money found due to the companypany as per Government valuation will be paid to the companypany

facts.text: Arbitration clause for disputes over payment of balance after valuation, arbitrator a high government officer rank of Divisional Commissioner or higher.

anchor.surface_text: That in the case of any difference or dispute between,the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the-sole arbitration of a single arbitrator who should be a high government officer of the provincial government of rank equal to or higher than a Divisional Commissioner

facts.text: Arbitration clause contained in letter dated 13th October 1949, accepted by company in letter dated 17th October 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration clause is companytained in a letter dated 13th October, 1949, and was substantially accepted by the companypany in its letter dated 17th October, 1949.

facts.text: State took over undertaking on 28th October 1949 and paid Rs. five lakhs to company.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the agreement the respondent took over the undertaking on 28th October, 1949, and also made a payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany.

facts.text: On 19th January 1950, company sent valuation of assets Rs. 22,06,072 to Chief Electrical Engineer Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th January, 1950, the companypany sent a statement of valuation of the assets amounting to RS. 22,06,072, to the Chief Electrical Engineer, Bihar.

facts.text: Chief Electrical Engineer stated company valuation fantastic, rough valuation approx five lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Electrical Engineer characterized the valuation of 22 lakhs by the companypany as fantastic and stated that according to a rough valuation the amount would be approximately five lakhs

facts.text: Company declined to give further details, stated time essence of contract, extended to 15th February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany declined to give any further details and stated that time was of the essence of the. companytract and it would be extended from 28th January, to 15th February, 1950

facts.text: On 6th April 1950, Chief Electrical Engineer intimated valuation Rs. 6,56,221.

anchor.surface_text: On 6th April, 1950, the Chief Electrical Engineer intimated that the valuation amounted to Rs. 6,56,221.

facts.text: State Government intimated appointment of Mr. M. S. Rao, C.S. as sole arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: No reply to this letter was received and the State Government intimated to the companypany that as difference and dispute had arisen relating to valuation, Mr. M. S. Rao, C.S. -was being appointed as sole arbitrator to decide the dispute.

facts.text: Company instituted Title Suit No. 47 of 1950 on 28th September 1950 after section 80 notice.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th September, 1950, the companypany instituted the suit, the subject-matter the application for stay, after necessary numberice under section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: In plaint, company alleged State failed to make valuation or payment by 15th March 1950, committed breach, company rescinded agreement and forfeited Rs. five lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged ,that as the State Government had failed and neglected to make its valuation or to make payment to the companypany by -the 15th March, 1950, it companymitted a breach of the agreement and by reason of this breach the companypany had rescinded the agreement and had forfeited the sum of five lakhs paid as advance by the State.

facts.text: State filed application under section 34 on 9th October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th October, 1950, the State Government filed the present appli- cation under section 34, of the Indian Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed stay application holding suit not in respect of matter agreed to be referred.

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the suit was numberin respect of any matter agreed to be referred, and that the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to stay the proceedings. In the result the stay application was dismissed.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court, High Court held dispute within arbitration clause and stayed suit.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the State Government appealed to the High Court. The High Court held that the dispute in the suit was one which arose out of or was in respect of the agreement and that the question in the suit was directly within the scope of the arbitration clause.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on 22nd May 1951 under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of this companyrt dated 22nd May, 1951, the companypany was granted special leave under article 136 1  of the Constitution.
under section 34 of the Indian- Arbitration Act for stay of proceedings in a suit filed by the companypany on 28th September, 1950.

concepts.interpretation: Legal proceedings must be in respect of matter agreed to be referred; court must be satisfied no sufficient reason not to refer and applicant ready/willing to arbitrate.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.
that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed is in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

issues.text: Whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simon L. C. in Heyman v. Darwins Ltd 1 . the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

issues.text: What is the present dispute about

anchor.surface_text: Now as regards the first question, viz., what is the present dispute about, the answer is to be gathered from paragraphs 14 to 17 of the plaint.

issues.text: What disputes the arbitration clause covers

anchor.surface_text: the clause here is that if any difference or dispute arises between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the sole arbitration

issues.text: Whether the validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit can be gone into by the court exercising jurisdiction under section 34

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one.

arguments.claim: State Government failed and neglected to make valuation or payment by 15th March 1950, committing breach of agreement

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged ,that as the State Government had failed and neglected to make its valuation or to make payment to the companypany by -the 15th March, 1950, it companymitted a breach of the agreement

anchor.surface_text: and by reason of this breach the companypany had rescinded the agreement and had forfeited the sum of five lakhs paid as advance by the State. The companypany prayed inter alia for the reliefs of declaration

arguments.claim: Company instituted suit with dishonest and mala fide motive to avoid arbitration on incorrect allegations

anchor.surface_text: It was stated therein that the companypany had with a, dishonest and mala fide motive and with a view to avoid the decision of the matter in dispute in arbitration instituted the suit on incorrect and false allegations.

arguments.claim: Arbitration agreement still subsisting, valid, binding, not rescinded as alleged

anchor.surface_text: that the arbitration agreement was still subsisting and valid and binding on the parties and could not be taken as having been rescinded as alleged by the company

anchor.surface_text: that the cause of action as alleged in the plaint being non-compliance with the agreement the suit arose out of and related to the agreement and was covered by the arbitration clause

anchor.surface_text: and that the State Government was ready and willing to have the dispute settled by arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The company denied the allegations of mala fides and pleaded that the arbitration clause was no longer in existence and that even assuming it to be in existence, the suit was in no way connected with the same

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the suit was not in respect of any matter agreed to be referred, and that the court had no jurisdiction to stay the proceedings. In the result the stay application was dismissed.

arguments.claim: Dispute in suit arose out of or in respect of agreement, directly within arbitration clause scope

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the dispute in the suit was one which arose out of or was in respect of the agreement and that the question in the suit was directly within the scope of the arbitration clause.

arguments.court_reasoning: Misread clause as broad; erred on merits

arguments.claim: Under s34, proceeding must be in respect of matter agreed to be referred within arbitration agreement ambit

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

arguments.claim: Test for dispute within clause: (a) what is dispute, (b) what disputes clause covers (Heyman v Darwins)

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simon L. C. in Heyman v. Darwins Ltd. the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

arguments.claim: Present dispute from plaint paras 14-17: breach, failure to value/pay timely (time essence), rescission, forfeiture; not for valuation/payment

anchor.surface_text: Now as regards the first question, viz., what is the present dispute about, the answer is to be gathered from paragraphs 14 to 17 of the plaint.

arguments.claim: Arbitration clause covers only difference/dispute over payment of balance found due after valuation

anchor.surface_text: the clause here is that if any difference or dispute arises between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the sole arbitration

arguments.claim: Clause narrow: only valuation pure and simple; breach/rescission/time essence outside scope

anchor.surface_text: It only confers jurisdiction on the arbitrator on the question of valuation of the undertaking pure and simple and does not say that all disputes arising out of the agreement or in respect of it will be decided by arbitration. Questions relating to the breach of contract or its rescission are outside the reach of this clause.

arguments.claim: Under s34, court function limited: only if claim within submission to arbitration, not merits/validity/frivolousness

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one.

arguments.claim: High Court erred deciding merits (no time stipulation for payment, pay after award)

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami J., with whom Rai J. concurred, held that upon a perusal of the terms of the contract and of the correspondence it was obvious that no stipulation was made that the compensation money should be paid within the period of three months... Now this is the very point which would be in issue in the suit itself, and the learned Judge was in error

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat all disputes arising out of the agreement would be referred to arbitration, it companyld then probably have been said that the scope of the suit w

arguments.court_reasoning: s34 limits to scope, not merits

arguments.claim: Unlike broad clauses in Heyman, Harinagar, Associated Livestock; this clause narrow

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges in the High Court seem to have thought that the arbitration clause here had been drafted broadly... Their reliance on... Harinagar Sugar Mills... Governor-General... also shows that they were under the same erroneous impression.

holdings.text: The legal proceeding sought to be stayed under section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of section 34; where suit outside submission, court must refuse stay.

holdings.text: Whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause depends on (a) what the dispute is, and (b) what disputes the clause covers.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simon L. C. in Heyman v. Darwins Ltd 1 . the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts test from English precedent Heyman v Darwins; applies to interpret scope.

holdings.text: The dispute in the suit concerns the defendant's breach by failing to value/pay timely (time of essence), plaintiff's rescission of agreement, and forfeiture of advance; not valuation or payment of balance.

anchor.surface_text: Now as regards the first question, viz., what is the present dispute about, the answer is to be gathered from paragraphs 14 to 17 of the plaint. It is averred therein that the Government of Bihar committed breach of the agreement and failed to make any, valuation of the undertaking or pay the balance of the compensation money, that time being of the essence of the contract,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gathered directly from plaint paras 14-17; no claim for valuation/compensation.

holdings.text: The arbitration clause covers only differences/disputes over payment of balance found due after valuation, limited to valuation pure and simple; excludes breach, rescission, time essence issues.

anchor.surface_text: the clause here is that if any difference or dispute arises between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the sole arbitration of a single arbitrator. The scheme of the agreement is that the Government was to make a valuation as laid down in the Indian Electricity Act within three, months of taking over the undertaking

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of clause language; narrow scope unlike broad clauses; scheme of agreement limits to valuation disputes.

holdings.text: The suit dispute does not fall within the arbitration clause; stay under section 34 must be refused.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement. Where, however, a suit is commenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission, the court is bound to refuse a stay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s34 via Heyman test: dispute is rescission/breach (i3), clause narrow (i4); outside ambit.

holdings.text: Under section 34, court cannot examine validity, merits, or frivolousness of plaintiff's claim; limited to whether claim falls within arbitration submission.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. The only point in such cases to be decided is whether the claim which is brought- whether it is good, bad or indifferent comes within the submission to arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdictional limit of s34 inquiry; cites Monro v Bognor; distinguishes from merits trial.

holdings.text: High Court erred by interpreting clause broadly, relying on broad-clause precedents, and deciding merits (no time stipulation for payment).

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami J., with whom Rai J. concurred, held that upon a perusal of the terms of the contract and of the correspondence it was obvious that no stipulation was made that the compensation money should be paid within the period of three months... Now this is the very point which would be in issue in the suit itself, and the learned Judge was in error

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court exceeded s34 limits, misread narrow clause as broad; distinguishes Harinagar, Associated Livestock.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simona L. C. in Heyman v. Daruins Ltd 1 . the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a companytract must depend on  a  what is the dispute, and  b  what disputes the arbitration clause companyers.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause depends on (a) what the dispute is and (b) what disputes the clause covers; repudiation based on contract terms is referable, but avoidance for reasons outside the contract is not.
precedents.cited_holding: the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

precedents.citation: Monro v. Bognor Urban Council 1 1915 3 K.B. i67

anchor.surface_text: those companysiderations, as pointed out by Banks J in Monro v. Bognor Urban Council 1 , are material only if the question to be companysidered is whether the case made was a frivolous and vexatious one

precedents.cited_proposition: In stay applications, the court examines only if the claim falls within the arbitration submission, not its merits or whether frivolous unless sham; look to the plaint.

precedents.citation: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd. 2 1937 41 C.W.N. 563 A.I.R. 1948 Cal 230

anchor.surface_text: Their reliance on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.   in support of the decision indicates the error. In that case the arbitration clause was drafted in a companyprehensive language

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Disputes arising out of the agreement referred to arbitration under a comprehensive arbitration clause.

precedents.citation: Governor-General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd. 3

anchor.surface_text: Their reference to the case of Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd. 3  also shows that they were under the same erroneous impression. In this case the arbitration clause was in these terms -

precedents.case_name: Governor-General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Any dispute or difference arising out of the contract shall be referred to arbitration.
precedents.cited_holding: Any dispute or difference arising out of the contract shall be referred to the arbitration of the officer sanctioning the contract whose decision shall be final and binding.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the agreement is that the Government was to make a valuation as laid down in the Indian Electricity Act within three, months of taking over the undertaking and any balance of money found due to the companypany as per Government valuation was to be paid by the Government, and in case of over-payment, the excess paid to the companypany on account of the on account payment of rupees five lakhs mentioned in paragraph 1 had to be refunded to government. In the case of any difference between the parties over the valuation as arrived at by the Government and that arrived at by the companypany, such difference or dispute, including the claim for additional companypensation of twenty per cent. had to be referred to arbitration a scope of it is arbitration clause is a very narrow one.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order granting stay set aside; arbitration clause held narrow and not covering dispute on breach or rescission of agreement; suit allowed to proceed

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

The scheme of the agreement is that the Government was to make a valuation as laid down in the Indian Electricity Act within three, months of taking over the undertaking and any balance of money found due to the companypany as per Government valuation was to be paid by the Government, and in case of over-payment, the excess paid to the companypany on account of the on account payment of rupees five lakhs mentioned in paragraph 1 had to be refunded to government. In the case of any difference between the parties over the valuation as arrived at by the Government and that arrived at by the companypany, such difference or dispute, including the claim for additional companypensation of twenty per cent. had to be referred to arbitration a scope of it is arbitration clause is a very narrow one.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement. Where, however, a suit is commenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission, the court is bound to refuse a stay.

The scheme of the agreement is that the Government was to make a valuation as laid down in the Indian Electricity Act within three, months of taking over the undertaking and any balance of money found due to the companypany as per Government valuation was to be paid by the Government, and in case of over-payment, the excess paid to the companypany on account of the on account payment of rupees five lakhs mentioned in paragraph 1 had to be refunded to government. In the case of any difference between the parties over the valuation as arrived at by the Government and that arrived at by the companypany, such difference or dispute, including the claim for additional companypensation of twenty per cent. had to be referred to arbitration a scope of it is arbitration clause is a very narrow one.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. The only point in such cases to be decided is whether the claim which is brought- whether it is good, bad or indifferent comes within the submission to arbitration.

In the case of any difference between the parties over the valuation as arrived at by the Government and that arrived at by the companypany, such difference or dispute, including the claim for additional companypensation of twenty per cent. had to be referred to arbitration a scope of it is arbitration clause is a very narrow one.
